intro: Crepis rubialis, commonly known as the red-headed thistle, is a flowering plant in the family Asteraceae. It is native to Europe and is characterized by its hairy, reddish stems and spiny leaves. The plant produces small, yellow flowers arranged in a composite head, typical of the daisy family. It thrives in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and disturbed soils. Crepis rubialis is often found in meadows and along roadsides, where it plays a role in supporting local pollinator populations.
